Trucking & Diabetes

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎01-09-2012 04:49 PM

My husband was recently diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes.  He drives a truck for living all local work, no over the road.  Everything I've read so far from FMCSA & MSP says if he is taking insulin they will disqualify him from getting his medical card.  Has anyone had to deal with this?  What have you done?  I'm not going to lie, I do not want to be the one to tell my husband this!  That's why I'm researching more information first before I tell him. 

Report Inappropriate Content

‎01-09-2012 05:04 PM

Hi Bossychell,

 

One of my brother's was an OTR O/O along with his wife.  He couldn't get his BG under control and was put on insulin.  No longer drives a big truck.....  In looking at his diet, I know that if he were to limit his excessive carb intake he may have been able to avoid the insulin.  Not everyone can make that lifestyle change though.  Probably not what you want to hear.

 

Tom

Diagnosed T2 October, 2009  A1c 6.8
Currently on Metformin ER 1000mg per day
Last A1c 09/21/2013  5.4

‎01-09-2012 05:05 PM

It is true that insulin will disqualify him initially.  He can, however, get a waiver but it takes a lot of work.  Some states don't allow the waiver, but the federal government will.  It can also get expensive to get the waiver.  He will have to get an Okay from a board certified endocrinologist first.  He will also have to get this okay from him every 3 months.  It will be easier for him if he will work with his physician to control the diabetes with diet, exercise, and/or oral meds if it is at all possible.  As long as he stays off of insulin, he will have no problem.  He may have to get a physical yearly rather than every 2 years, but that's not a big deal.  Don't put it off.  He needs to hear this so he knows what to expect.


"No one can make you feel inferior without your consent." -- Eleanor Roosevelt


Toujeo 70 units in the morning and at bedtime
Novolog 50 units with each meal
Metformin 1000 mg twice daily
Glipizide ER 5 mg daily
Neurontin (gabapentin) 300 mg three times daily (neuropathy)
Metoprolol 50 mg twice daily (hypertension)
lisinopril 40 mg daily (hypertension)
Crestor 10mg at bedtime (hypercholesterolemia)
Arthrotec 50 three times daily (Rheumatoid Arthritis)
Multivitamin daily
Aspirin 81 mg daily
Lovaza 2 gm twice daily

‎01-09-2012 05:27 PM

bossychell wrote:

My husband was recently diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes.  He drives a truck for living all local work, no over the road.  Everything I've read so far from FMCSA & MSP says if he is taking insulin they will disqualify him from getting his medical card.  Has anyone had to deal with this?  What have you done?  I'm not going to lie, I do not want to be the one to tell my husband this!  That's why I'm researching more information first before I tell him. 

 

I believe the rules over there are similar to here. Insulin use disqualifies a driver from heavy vehicles in my state.

 

Depending on whether he is still producing his own insulin, which is very likely as a new type 2, it is possible he can avoid a need for injected insulin if he makes appropriate changes to his lifestyle, especially in terms of diet and exercise. I give more details on that here: Getting Started

 

Would it be possible to get him to drop in here to say g'day to us? We may be able to offer suggestions to assist him. We are diabetics, not doctors, but there is a wealth of experience here.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)
Born Under a Wandering Star (Latest: Ella to Kandy, Sri Lanka)

‎01-09-2012 06:33 PM

If he has a CDL, it's true. It's also true he might get a waiver. It is a pain in the patootie to do so. If he can get great control with the D, and keep it, he'll be ok. Otherwise I suggest he starts looking for another job.

I loved driving. But I gave up my CDL because of the insulin. My health is more important.and sometimes, no matter what you do, the pancreas poops out, and you require insulin. YMMV
Barb T2 Omni Pod since 1-09

‎01-10-2012 07:22 AM

I lost my CDL because of the insulin issue. Was on it and the doc refused to sign the medical card needed for the license. In researching the law at the time, it was put into effect because drivers were injecting insulin while driving, semi drivers mainly.

bossychell wrote:

My husband was recently diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes.  He drives a truck for living all local work, no over the road.  Everything I've read so far from FMCSA & MSP says if he is taking insulin they will disqualify him from getting his medical card.  Has anyone had to deal with this?  What have you done?  I'm not going to lie, I do not want to be the one to tell my husband this!  That's why I'm researching more information first before I tell him. 

You can read more about the rules for commerical drivers' licenses and employment discrimination at this page from the American Diabetes Association:

 

Commericial Driver's License

 

"Molly" (aka mollythed)
Type 2 diabetes diagnosed in 1995, now managed with Lantus, Novolog and Metformin; diet and exercise.
My late husband had diabetes. My three adult sons also have type 2 diabetes.

Re: Trucking & Diabetes

‎01-10-2012 06:01 PM

It's not really emloyers discriminating against diabetics when it comes to Commercial Driving.  It's more a government issue with safety.  It would be bad enough for a person in a car to lose consciousness because of low blood sugar, but can you imagine if they are driving a vehicle that weighs more than 80,000 pounds?  The employer can only hire someone with a valid medical card to go with the CDL.  It's possible for a diabetic to get this medical card, even when using insulin, but it takes a bit more work than it does for a non-diabetic or even a diabetic that is not using insulin.  I was a commercial driver when I was first diagnosed.  I know my family history and I knew tht someday I would be on insulin.  I got out of the industry before that happened.  I am now on insulin.  So far, I have never had a low, but I would hate to be driving a tractor-trailer if I do have one.  All of this is why I see the OP's husband needs to know what is going on so he can decide whether it is going to be worth the trouble to keep that health card or whether he would rather start working to do something other than driving.  His past experience could be useful in other aspects of trucking rather than actually driving.


"No one can make you feel inferior without your consent." -- Eleanor Roosevelt

‎01-10-2012 11:14 PM

It just breaks my heart to hear things like this, I too was put into this position 2  years ago. I was a truck driver for 33 years, started when I was 18. I was not on insulin when my CDL got disqualified. What happened is the time ran out for me to get my new medical card. I tried 9 times to get my DoT physical, if it wasnt one thing it was another...blood sugar to high, leaking to much protein thru kidneys, or both at same time. Something ur husband might want to try, if hes only having an issue with blood sugar, is to start a VERY VERY low carb diet. Being a local driver, he should have time for exercise also. He needs to take this serious if he wants to continue to drive a truck. Doing it this way may buy him some time before he goes in for his DoT physical to get his # down.

 

It was a hard pill for me to swallow after a 33 year driving career being taken away.  The last 16 years I drove in Chicago, for the Teamsters, and it was the best job I ever had. Please have a sit down talk with him and explain everything to him about getting his numbers down. Not only for his job, but for more so, his health. Good luck, hope to see in the post that he passes his DoT.
